text: So the super low vol environment of 2017 is what actually had led me to become very directly involved. And so if you remember, this happened in 2014 and 2015 as well, you entered into this regime where you would have days where the S&P would move at an annualized rate of volatility in the 2%, 3%, 4% sort of range, right? Something you had never seen before in history. And in understanding that trade, it actually became very clear that there was a structural feature that had occurred in the market that was a function of regulatory arbitrage. And so just very specifically, something called CCAR, capital adequacy ratios, is a byproduct of the Volcker rules. Those had an arbitrage difference between short volatility positions and long equity positions. The capital that was required to carry a long equity position, you had to ensure effectively hold capital, but you also had to ensure that you had a long equity position. So you had to hold capital against that equity long as a bank for an immediate 30% decline, effectively repeating the events of 1987. The analogous position for a short volatility position was a 10-point jump in the VIX, right? Now, that's off of whatever level that you started with. And quite frankly, that's an absurd comparison because most estimates of the VIX behavior in 1987 that it went from somewhere around 16 to somewhere in the neighborhood of 140. So not at all comparable at all. But when you look at the VIX, it's not at all comparable at all. It's not at all comparable at all. But what it had created was conditions where, for capital efficiency reasons, everybody on the street would prefer to hold their positions as a short volatility expression. This was occurring simultaneously alongside the growth of the VIX ETFs, and in particular, the inverse VIX ETFs. And so you were creating conditions where the volatility surface and the volatility market was increasingly driving the behavior in the equity markets. And you could mechanically see this through the hedging activity that was occurring. I've shared, pretty broadly, a video that shows the dynamics of what an algorithmic balancing of Greek exposures looks like. It's like an inverted pendulum, where you're trying to balance your delta hedging to hold your Greek exposures. If you do that with algorithms, you can bring it to fantastically low realized volatility levels. And that's exactly what we were seeing in the markets. So as I was trying to understand this, it became clear that this supply of volatility coming out of the retail space in products like XIV was a critical contributor. And then I became aware of a second component, which is a competing product. So it wasn't actually XIV, it was SVXY, which was offered by ProShares, had long dated leap put options against it. What had become painfully clear to anyone who was paying attention to it was that this had become very much a tail wagging the dog dynamic. And the behavior of those indices had led to effectively a rising beta of the VIX relative to the S&P. And so historically, in today's market, we've seen a lot of people think about the VIX as a move of the S&P 500. And so today, you would think about the beta of the VIX in terms of its move as a multiple of the move of the S&P 500. It's normally about 4 to 6x. So a 1% decline in the S&P typically translates to a 4 to 6% jump in the VIX, in point terms, typically more often. By 2017, that beta had picked up to the point that when I got into my argument on stage, and by the way, it was Chris Cole and I presenting and highlighting this short vol dynamic that existed in the market. We were both very, very attuned to it. And Nick Cherney from the audience pipes up because we've flagged XIV as a critical dynamic here and says, you don't understand the product at all, which was fun, because we ended up, we did understand the product. But that beta had gone from basically minus 4 to minus 22. And XIV had a very particular structure to it. It had a force majeure clause at 85% decline, that if the market, if it fell by 85% in a single day, Credit Suisse, the sponsor, the company, the company would be able to, and actually the obligation to shut it to avoid taking any losses. It was actually an ETN as compared to an ETF. And so a very, very simple calculation was, well, wait a second, if you're running a 22 beta, and it is an 85%, minus 22 beta, and there's an 85% shutdown, well, all you need is a 4% decline in the S&P for this to occur. How frequently does a 4% decline in the S&P happen? Well, guess what? The answer turns out to be this roughly 95% probability that that will occur over any given two-year period. We've seen multiple of those in the past couple of years. And that formed the basis of my pushback to Nick and saying, look, I think there's a 95% chance your product goes to zero at some point over the next two years. His belief was because they had modeled the relationship between the futures, and they'd assumed a stable beta, that this would survive the crash of 87. Long story short, on a 3.9% decline in the S&P on February 5, 2018, the product went to zero. We ended up doing extraordinarily well at TL Macro, where I was the first to get a 3.9% decline in the S&P. And so, I was able to get a 3.9% decline in the S&P. And so, I was managing Peter Thiel's capital at that point. We'd taken somewhere in the neighborhood of $250 million notional short against the SVXY that ended up working out very well. And the other funny part of that story, and it's just a good indication of why you should always take into consideration your counterparties, is when we put that trade on, I made a point of explaining to my counterparties at Merrill and JP Morgan and a couple of other places, I know you want to hold this risk. I know you think I'm crazy for doing this. Let me walk you through this and explain why you do not want to be left holding this bag. And of course, afterwards, in a form of gratitude, they basically released all the details to the press. And that's why it became relatively famous.
